metadata.title: How to Get a Data Science Internship — Technical Expertise vs Personality | by Low Wei Hong | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to Get a Data Science Internship — Technical Expertise vs Personality
metadata.description: Complete strategies you need to know before going to a data science internship interview.

all_paragraphs: The expert in anything was once a beginner — Helen Hayes

Previously, when I was a student still studying at university, I wanted to get a data science internship. I wanted to get it so badly that I applied to so many companies, but only got a few replies from them.

To be more specific, less than 10% of the companies I applied to replied to my application. Not only that, when I saw the description of the internship postings, the requirements were to have strong technical skills, excellent grades, in-dept machine learning knowledge and etc.
I was lost. I had neither a strong technical background nor previous experience in data science internships. I was just looking for my first data science internship.
Here are some of the questions I received from LinkedIn on how to land a data science internship.
I knew how it felt to be working so hard but still not getting what you want.
But if I told you that experience or technical background may not matter so much to get a data science internship, would you be interested?
In this article, I will share how you could get your first data science internship.
Now, let’s ask yourself the questions below.
Why do you need to get a data science internship?
And then, change to your hiring manager’s perspective.
Why do you need to hire interns?
After asking these two questions, do you find a common answer that you and your hiring manager are looking for?

One of the answers to the first question would be to learn data science, to know what skills a data scientist should have so that you can learn. However, what is the qualifications, skills or etc which you could bring to the table so that the hiring manager will hire you?

Imagine that the hiring manager is looking for interns who can help with some data annotation tasks and also evaluate various machine learning models. Meaning he or she is not looking for a person who has a strong technical background.

She might just want to find a person who is willing to work on some tasks that are not machine learning related. In other words, the hiring manager is looking for a person who has the personality that she is looking for.

For instance, given a data labeling task, you may think this is a very manual process. When your mentor is training models on your dataset and finds out that most of the labels annotated by you are incorrect, she will feel that she has wasted her time on trusting on your work.

But what if she is looking for a person who has a great personality to work with? Once she’s satisfied with the task given to you, I am sure she will be willing to teach you what you are interested in.

Let’s say the hiring manager is searching for someone to assist her in solving some of the hardest problems she is facing. In other words, she wants to bring in someone who has strong technical skills and machine learning knowledge.

In this case, the candidate she required will have to have the ability to read research papers, coming out with great ideas to solve problems, clean codes, make the current codes more efficient and etc.
Therefore, the hiring manager would have higher expectations for the candidate. In a nutshell, the candidate is expected to equip with strong technical skills.
Now, I guess you have a clearer picture of what a hiring manager is expecting. Therefore, let me share how you should prepare yourself in order to get your first data science internship!

If you are a person, who does not have a strong technical background, here are some of my suggestions. First, you should demonstrate a good personality during your interview. What is considered a good personality to have? For instance, hard-working, willing to learn, passionate about machine learning, independent and etc.

Think of this as your hiring manager perspective, if you do not have a technical background, but as long you are willing to learn and put in your hard work, most of the time, he or she will be willing to give you a chance. This is provided that you are not applying to the internship which requires a strong technical background.

Besides, don’t be picky about the company or job scope. If you got the data science internship, maybe most of your time will be spent on manual tasks. However, if you manage to clear the task faster, and you show that your technical skills really improve a lot in a short period of time, your manager will give you the chance to try to train some models. On the other hand, don’t forget that this internship will bring you more internship opportunities after that.

Moreover, having a great project to demonstrate is also very important. What I am saying here is not school projects, but interesting real-world projects. If you are interested to know which kind of projects to show, comment below!

You may ask your coursemates or friends to assist you. Publishing your code to GitHub is not the end of the story. You should get someone who knows nothing about data science, and you present the project to your friend in such a way that he or she knows what you are talking about.
On the other hand, spend some time on networking events. If you are able to show them a great first impression, you will have a high chance to get an interview.

If you are someone who does have the technical expertise, but still can’t find an internship, here are some ways you can take note of. If you are aiming for those top companies, practice your programming skills.

There are many websites which you could refer to such as Leetcode, Topcoder, Coderbyte and etc. If you are a lazy type of person, ask your seniors, friends, or even check out glassdoor to see whether there is anyone who shares the interview question. You will be shocked that sometimes you could even find the answer to the interview question there.

Besides, practice, practice and practice your presentation. Don’t let your presentation screw up your great project. I couldn’t emphasize this enough because I saw too many interns screwed up because of their presentation during the actual interview. They might have interesting projects to show, but after they finish their presentation, I still can’t catch what they are trying to show. Remember, data science is not only about coding, but also to present your findings clearly.
If you know you are always unable to answer questions related to the machine learning knowledge, do spend time brushing up your knowledge.

Not only that, show interesting projects. Remember to clean up your codes and insert neat comments. Besides, do pay some attention to your resume. Once when I interviewed an intern, his or her portfolio link showed in the resume can’t be accessed.
Personality is still very important in this case. Show that you have a great personality to work with so that your potential boss will take you.
There is no perfect formula that exists to get a data science internship, but there are ways you can work out to get it!
You get what you work for, not what you wish for — Daniel Milstein
Thank you so much for reading until the end. If you have any questions, feel free to comment below!
Believe me, you will get one if you follow my advice!
All the best to get your first data science internship and wish you an early Merry Christmas! 🎄
